awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Novel machine learning framework for the classification of non-mydriatic retinal images
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is an artificial intelligence (AI)-based method to screen diabetic retinopathy (DR), the leading cause of vision impairment and blindness in the US. DR affects almost 4 million people in the US and is associated with direct annual costs of almost $500 M. If diagnosed early, clinical treatment and lifestyle changes can halt the progression of the disease, preventing blindness. However, retinal exams currently require expensive equipment and invasive eye dilation that restrict screenings to ophthalmology or optometry practices, leading to the under-diagnosis of the condition, particularly in underserved populations. This project advances a system with a new camera and a machine learning approach to enable recognition of DR and other retinal disorders by clinicians.

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project seeks to explore the feasibility of developing a novel software-enabled non-mydriatic fundus camera that can identifiy DR. The proposed innovation is based on: 1) a portable camera that uses near-infrared (NIR) light, invisible to the human eye, to illuminate the retina and acquire fundus images, enabling the use of the device by non-specialists; 2) a novel framework based on transfer learning, which trains Neural Networks with a limited amount of training data (100 images). In this project, a prototype system will collect NIR retinal images, with the goal of developing an AI classification algorithm capable of processing these images. In parallel, a new image processing algorithm will be developed to improve the resolution of the NIR images, based on contrast normalization methods and noise reduction techniques.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Diabetic Retinopathy (DR) is the leading cause of vision impairment and blindness in the US and is the fifth most common cause of vision loss worldwide. This condition affects almost 9.6 million people in the US and of which 1.84 million people are affected with vision-threatening DR. If diagnosed early, clinical treatment and lifestyle changes can halt the progression of the disease, preventing blindness. Currently, the retinal exams for the diagnosis of ocular diseases such as DR are performed using expensive slit lamps, laser retina scanners, or Optical Coherence Tomography machines (up to $120,000). Additionally, the diagnostic process necessitates pupil dilation, requiring the application of mydriatic drugs on patients' eyes, which restricts the use of these technologies to well-funded optometry practices. Non-mydriatic fundus photography offers a promising alternative to these methods. The use of such cameras, coupled with artificial intelligence (AI), could support retinal screening at primary care centers enabling increased access to retinal screening.

Ai-RiS is developing a low-cost NIR non-mydriatic fundus camera with a novel machine learning framework that seamlessly integrates into the workflow of primary care clinics enabling automated recognition of DR and other ocular diseases with performance comparable to that of human experts. The novelty lies in its sequential transfer training methods that allow to accurately train the screening tool with dramatically fewer training images than that would be required with conventional methods. The training resulted in an autonomous image recognition system that can recognize and classify portable NIR-enabled retinal images based on the pathological patterns it observes.

Using the proprietary transfer learning methods Ai-RiS has fine-tuned the trained neural network using a small retrain set composed of a subset of NIR images. Image processing algorithms such as histogram equalization, wavelet denoising, diffusion filtering and others were used to enhance the image quality and improve the readability for the physicians. The performance of the model was substantially improved through the application of finetuning and dataset enhancement techniques, both individually and in combination. By independently employing finetuning, notable enhancements in model performance compared to the baseline were observed. Similarly, dataset enhancement settings yielded substantial improvements on their own. However, it was the synergistic effect of applying both finetuning and dataset enhancement that yielded the best-performing system. The process has been designed to scale continuously as new portable images are collected to further fine-tune the deep learning model.

The results of SBIR Phase I provide promising evidence of the improved performance of Ai-RiS's approach and suggest that as more portable camera images are collected, a significant potential exists to improve the model's performance much further beyond its current level. Ai-RiS's retinal screening system for DR detection truly solves primary care physician and patient pain points as it is: a) capable of imaging the retina without requiring pupil dilation drops, b) able to immediately interpret retinal images of the patient, c) portable and d) capable of operating with minimum supervision. By developing the retinal screening headset device for automated detection of DR, Ai-RiS will bring forward effective research strategies and workflow for the early detection of other ocular disorders such as Age-related Macular Degeneration, prescreen Glaucoma, retinal detachment, and retinal vein occlusion.
